org.jamesframework.core.problems

Class ProblemWithData<SolutionType extends Solution,DataType>

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.jamesframework.core.problems.ProblemWithData<SolutionType,DataType>
  • Type Parameters:
    SolutionType - solution type corresponding to this problem
    DataType - type of underlying data
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    Problem<SolutionType>
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SubsetProblemWithData

    public abstract class ProblemWithData<SolutionType extends Solution,DataType>
extends Object
implements Problem<SolutionType>

    Represents an abstract problem that separates data from the objective and possible constraints. The problem contains data of some specific data type (see parameter DataType), and solutions are evaluated -- or possibly rejected -- based on a combination of an objective and constraints, which rely on this data. Two types of constraints can be specified:

    • Rejecting constraints: any solution violating a rejecting constraint is immediately rejected, regardless of its evaluation. More precisely, for such solutions, rejectSolution(...) returns true.

    • Penalizing constraints assign a penalty to the evaluation calculated by the objective, which is usually designed to reflect the severeness of the violation. Solutions which are closer to satisfaction will then be favoured over solutions which violate the constraints more severely. In case of a maximizing objective, penalties are subtracted from the objective score, while they are added to it in case of a minimizing objective. No penalties are assigned to solutions satisfying the constraints.

    Author:
    Herman De Beukelaer

    • Constructor Detail

      • ProblemWithData

        public ProblemWithData(Objective<? super SolutionType,? super DataType> objective,
                       DataType data)
        Creates a new abstract problem with given objective and data. Any objective designed for the solution and data types of the problem, or more general types, is accepted. The objective can not be null, as it will be called to evaluate solutions.
        Parameters:
        objective - objective function
        data - underlying data
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if objective is null

      • addRejectingConstraint

        public void addRejectingConstraint(Constraint<? super SolutionType,? super DataType> constraint)
        Add a rejecting constraint to the problem. For any solution that violates such constraint, rejectSolution(...) will return true. Only constraints designed for the solution and data types of the problem, or more general types, are accepted.
        Parameters:
        constraint - rejecting constraint to add

      • removeRejectingConstraint

        public boolean removeRejectingConstraint(Constraint<? super SolutionType,? super DataType> constraint)
        Remove a rejecting constraint. Returns true if the constraint has successfully been removed.
        Parameters:
        constraint - rejecting constraint to be removed
        Returns:
        true if the problem contained the specified constraint

      • addPenalizingConstraint

        public void addPenalizingConstraint(PenalizingConstraint<? super SolutionType,? super DataType> constraint)
        Add a penalizing constraint to the problem. For a solution that violates a penalizing constraint, a penalty will be assigned to the objective score. Only penalizing constraints designed for the solution and data types of the problem, or more general types, are accepted.
        Parameters:
        constraint - penalizing constraint to add

      • removePenalizingConstraint

        public boolean removePenalizingConstraint(PenalizingConstraint<? super SolutionType,? super DataType> constraint)
        Remove a penalizing constraint. True is returned if the constraint has successfully been removed.
        Parameters:
        constraint - penalizing constraint to be removed
        Returns:
        true if the problem contained the specified constraint

      • rejectSolution

        public boolean rejectSolution(SolutionType solution)
        Checks whether any of the specified rejecting constraints are violated. If so, this method returns true.
        Specified by:
        rejectSolution in interface Problem<SolutionType extends Solution>
        Parameters:
        solution - solution to check against the rejecting constraints
        Returns:
        true if any rejecting constraint is violated

      • getViolatedConstraints

        public Set<Constraint<? super SolutionType,? super DataType>> getViolatedConstraints(SolutionType solution)
        Returns a set of all violated constraints (both rejecting and penalizing constraints). If the given solution satisfies all constraints, the returned set will be empty.
        Parameters:
        solution - solution for which violated constraints are determined
        Returns:
        set of all violated constraints (rejecting and penalizing)

      • evaluate

        public double evaluate(SolutionType solution)
        Evaluates a solution by taking into account both the score calculated by the objective function and the penalizing constraints (if any). First, the objective function is calculated for the given solution. Then, penalties are assigned for any violated penalizing constraint. Penalties are subtracted in case of maximization, and added in case of minimization. The resulting score is returned.
        Specified by:
        evaluate in interface Problem<SolutionType extends Solution>
        Parameters:
        solution - solution to be evaluated
        Returns:
        aggregated evaluation taking into account both the objective function and penalizing constraints
        See Also:
        Problem.isMinimizing()

      • isMinimizing

        public boolean isMinimizing()
        Indicates whether the underlying objective is minimizing.
        Specified by:
        isMinimizing in interface Problem<SolutionType extends Solution>
        Returns:
        true if the objective is minimizing
